step1.sentence: After three rounds of negotiation, both sides finally reached an agreement.

step2.story: They had been trying to reach an agreement for months. What finally moved the conversation was one side asking the other what a good outcome would look like for them — not what they wanted, but what they actually needed. The answer surprised both parties and made the agreement possible within a week.

step3.story: The labor agreement had taken fourteen months to reach. Observers who had watched only the public statements had assumed it was a story of two sides with incompatible positions. What the lead negotiator on each side knew was that the public statements were a different negotiation entirely — a performance for different audiences — and that the actual agreement had been built through a hundred small private exchanges, each one narrowing the distance between what was possible and what was acceptable. Reaching an agreement was rarely one moment. It was usually the accumulation of many smaller ones.
